alert.note: Alert for Coffee; Dale; Geneva; Henry; Houston (Alabama) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued December 14 at 2:10PM CST by NWS Tallahassee
info.description: ...Potential Increasing For Heavy Rainfall Across Much Of The Region... .Antecedent Conditions... Over the last three weeks, several heavy rainfall events across South Alabama, South Georgia, and the Florida Big Bend and Panhandle have led to overly saturated soils. While mainstem rivers are at normal levels, smaller basin rivers and streams are at above normal flows. Moreover, the saturated soils in these areas are primed for excessive runoff, which could lead to flash flooding, especially across much of the Florida Panhandle and Big Bend. .Forecast and Outlook... A strong Gulf low will develop on Saturday and move rapidly toward the region. Widespread moderate to occasionally heavy rainfall will overspread the region. Even though this system will move fairly quickly, the potential exists for very heavy rainfall to occur in a short period of time, which could lead to flash flooding, particularly in urban environments within South Alabama and Georgia as well as the Florida Big Bend and Panhandle. Some locations could experience 4-6 inches of rain with locally heavier totals throughout this event. While mainstem rivers will respond to these rainfall amounts, widespread river flooding is not likely, outside of the Ochlockonee River, where some threat of minor flooding exists. The smaller basin rivers and creeks are more vulnerable, like the Sopchoppy River in Wakulla County and Bear Creek in Bay County. These areas, should they receive 4-6 inches of rain, could easily flood. .Preparedness Information... There remains uncertainty as to where the heaviest rainfall will occur. However a flood watch may be required for some portion of the area on Friday. Now is a good time to prepare if you live in an area vulnerable to flooding. If you live in a flood zone, know your risk and be prepared to take action later this weekend should heavier rainfall occur. For the latest forecasts visit our website at https://weather. gov/tallahassee
